title: If we solve climate change, will we still face the existential threat of totalitarian governments due to AI technology and concentration of wealth controlled by politicians or big businesses? (See attached.) - Quora

response.answer_text: Geoff, corrupt government & corporatism will continue until society collapses from anthropogenic global warming & climate change, it is now too late to stop climate change. We could reduce the severity of disasters perhaps & avoid social collapse & our extinction if we were to stop the burning of fossil fuels NOW, but this is not going to happen. Society will likely collapse withing the next few decades, & the human race could be extinct by the end of the 21st century. Climate change is accelerating.'Uninhabitable hell': Climate change and disease threaten millions  Welcome to the Anthropocene Age. Will it be the end of us?  ‘High likelihood of human civilisation coming to end’ by 2050, report finds  Human society has 90% chance of collapsing in the next few decades. But why?  Inquiry hears natural disasters likely to become more intense and frequent in future | Sky News Australia  Anthropogenic climate change accelerating faster than earlier, natural analogs - Advanced Science News  Climate change is only going to make health crises like coronavirus more frequent and worse  'My home is touched by the sea': Climate change displacing one person every two seconds, Oxfam says  'Uninhabitable Hell:' UN Report Warns of Planet's Future for Millions Without Climate Action  All we have to do to save the human race from extinction is to stop burning fossil fuels, but it seems that this is too much to ask. The people prefer death over changing society & their environmentally damaging city lifestyles!!! Keith.

As often seems to be the case with futurist predictions, this one seems just a tad overblown. I am more worried about the real existential threat of climate change than the remote possibilities that any world government could impose a global totalitarian regime. As things stand now, it is difficult enough for federal systems, which are the best hope for a global authority, to maintain their stability In the face of various resistances from peripheral authorities representing local interests or empty-headed xenophobias. The prospect of global corporatist order is more immediate but tempered somewhat by market forces that already appear to have many companies taking stands on policies over which they have considerable influence but no real legitimate control.
